awd_titl_txt: Support of a Hybrid Format 2022 North American Membrane Society (NAMS) Meeting To Expand Access And Diversity
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will provide support for the audiovisual infrastructure required to host a hybrid, virtual and onsite, 2022 Meeting of the North American Membrane Society (NAMS) in Tempe, Arizona. NAMS is a premier membrane conference, providing outstanding technical sessions across the full breadth of topics within membrane science and technology. The theme of the 2022 meeting is "Membranes for Sustainability," where technical sessions will focus on communicating the latest developments and trends in membrane science geared towards improving sustainability. The meeting has a rich history as a forum for students, early-career researchers, and leaders in the field, from both industry and academia, to share their research and development outcomes, insights, and future directions. The hybrid meeting format allows attendees to decide how they wish to participate. Providing a virtual attendance option has been shown to reduce barriers to participation, such as the burden and cost of travel, and is expected to improve overall attendance and make the meeting globally accessible. This support for the hybrid meeting audiovisual infrastructure will ensure a positive, productive meeting experience for all attendees and promotes participation by diverse members of the membranes research community. The format also provides flexibility should pandemic-related travel restrictions arise.

The NAMS organizing committee is comprised of diverse North American researchers, and invited speakers from academia, industry, and government labs feature prominently in the program. The meeting will feature 30 technical sessions, daily plenary sessions, a poster session, and abundant unstructured discussion periods to catalyze new collaborative relationships and research ideas. All oral presentations by onsite and online speakers will be given through a live Zoom teleconference, with two-way communication and online session chairs to moderate discussions. Mentorship breakouts, sponsor sessions, and plenary talks will also be live through Zoom, such that all attendees are participating in real-time. The 2022 NAMS meeting will cover a variety of topics ranging from fundamental studies of membrane material science to process systems development and applications of membrane technology in water, bioprocessing, chemical separations, environmental systems, and energy. Historically, more than 400 leading membranologists from around the world participate in the NAMS meeting each year. This award will extend opportunities to meaningfully participate in the meeting to researchers who might, otherwise, be unable to attend in person. The effectiveness of the hybrid meeting format will be assessed through surveys and quantitative comparison with attendance profiles from prior meetings, and the findings will be disseminated through the society's website and a peer-reviewed publication.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to provide support for a hybrid conference format for the 2022 Annual Meeting of the North American Membrane Society (NAMS). NAMS is one of the premier membrane conferences in the world, providing outstanding technical sessions across the full breadth of topics within membrane science and technology. NAMS also has a long history of actively involving graduate students in its annual meeting.

 

Recently, the COVID-19 pandemic led to an increase in the use of online conference formats. While having numerous benefits including lower attendance costs and carbon footprint, these online conferences lacked essential elements of traditional conferences, namely in-person interaction and networking. This NSF supported project provided NAMS with the opportunity to host a hybrid conference (with both in-person and online attendees) aimed at achieving benefits associated with both in-person and online events. The hybrid format allowed for traditional in-person interaction amongst attendees while allowing online attendees to seamlessly interact with the technical content of the conference in real time. Additionally, the new hybrid format was well received by attendees, with most identifying it as their preferred conference format.

 

Intellectual Merit. 

Separations technology is critical to address the needs of society. Separation processes are used to produce safe drinking water, valuable medicines, key chemicals and fuels, and other products that help improve the human condition. Membrane-based separations offer a number of unique advantages compared to competing technologies including lower energy requirements, relative ease of scale-up, and no phase changes or chemical additives. For example, reverse osmosis (RO) systems for desalination typically require only 10% of the energy of comparable thermal processes.  The Freedonia Group (2015) recently projected that the market for membrane technology would increase at an annual rate of 8.5% over the next several years, reaching annual global sales of more than $28 billion by 2020 with approximately 25% of that within the U.S.

 

The 2022 NAMS Annual Meeting occurred from May 14-18, 2022. In response to COVID-19, the emerging hybrid format was explored and assessed using participant feedback and demographics. 361 (73%) attendees participated in-person in Tempe, AZ and the remaining 133 (27%) attendees participated online. Whova was used as the central platform for live streams and recordings of technical sessions as well as interaction amongst attendees. The meeting featured parallel technical sessions, plenary talks, a poster session, and many events geared towards networking, providing opportunities for membrane researchers, manufacturers, and end-users to learn about the latest developments in membrane science and technology. Further, the NAMS 2022 conference provided the scientific foundations to prepare new generations of a diverse workforce dedicated to the world of membrane applications; 44.9% of attendees were undergraduate students (4.5%), graduate students (34.6%) or postdocs (5.9%). 29.8% of attendees were from industry. Additionally, women and industry professionals made up larger percentages of the online attendees than the in-person attendees, suggesting that the online component of the conference increased participation from these groups. Additionally, survey data suggests that the hybrid format increased attendance at the NAMS 2022 meeting relative to an online-only or in-person only meeting. ~79% online attendees said they would not have attended NAMS 2022 if it was an in-person only event while ~45% of in-person attendees would not have attended NAMS 2022 if it were online only. The hybrid format was also well received by attendees, with 74% of survey respondents saying it was their preferred format for the NAMS 2022 meeting.

 

Data on attendee demographics, carbon footprint, and attendee experience were presented at a board meeting for the North American Membrane Society. Also, this data will be compared with data from other hybrid conferences as part of a research collaboration with the American Astronomical Society and the Deep Sea Biological Society. The goal of this collaboration is to publish our results in a peer-reviewed journal.

 

Broader Impacts. 

Support for hybrid and online participation in NAMS 2022 helped address a critical need to build the talent pool for workers in the membrane industry by expanding the reach of the conference to more students, postdocs, and early career industry and academic scientists. The anticipated >8% annual growth rate in the industry requires a highly skilled labor force that is well-prepared to contribute to the development and application of membrane technology to meet the growing needs of society for more sustainable separation solutions. This includes providing clean drinking water, facilitating, carbon dioxide capture, to the development of separations critical to the biopharmaceutical industry, all of which were key focal areas of NAMS 2022.

 

Additionally, the hybrid format of the NAMS 2022 conference decreased the carbon footprint of the meeting. The carbon footprint of the hybrid conference was reduced by a calculated 31.5% (~154 Tonnes CO2e) compared to a hypothetical case where all 494 attendees participated in-person.
